Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing Infrastructure Resiliency and Sustainability Through Robust Self-Healing Ductile Concrete - A New Paradigm

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
With the aging of civil infrastructure, deterioration in their function and safety is threatening the economy and quality of life in the US. While infrastructure aging is inevitable, deterioration is not, provided the paradigm of concrete design is shifted. Traditionally, concrete has been designed for damage prevention. This research is a new approach to concrete design that embodies damage control and damage management. In other words, concrete damage is allowed, but controlled to retain sufficient material integrity that subsequently recovers efficiently. As a result, civil infrastructure will be more sustainable and resilient. Specifically, concrete degradation over time is continuously counteracted by self-healing, eliminating costly cycles of repair. Under extreme loading such as that caused by an earthquake or a hurricane, sudden loss of capacity is limited, and self-recovery of functionality will proceed economically and rapidly. The ultimate goal of this project is to interrupt the ubiquitous infrastructure deterioration and safety concerns in the US through advanced materials engineering. Apart from enhancing education at the university level through integrated research and teaching, this project also aims to broaden its impact through outreach programs, including the EARTH-2050 TV STEM series targeted at over half a million high school students.

The objective of this project is to develop a new multi-scale model that embodies deep understanding of the physical, chemical and mechanical processes governing robust self-healing, thus addressing a knowledge gap that has limited the reliable application of such functionality in the field. The success of the damage control and management approach relies on the efficient development of a ductile concrete with the capacity to sustain overloads with controlled microcracks, and to subsequently mend them consistently without external intervention. Through this research combining novel experimental techniques, analytical modeling and numerical modeling, new knowledge will be generated linking micro and nano scale phenomena of self-healing product formation inside microcracks, to meso scale phenomena of crack closure and recovery of load transfer capacity across crack faces, to macro scale phenomena governing the recovery of stiffness, strength and ductility in the ductile concrete. Self-healing data under loaded condition will be obtained for the first time. The complex self-healing behavior that depends on material age and composition, damage degree, and environmental conditions, will be illuminated and resolved through the multi-scale experiments and models derived in this research. The hypothesis of micro-composite self-formation inside microcracks of the ductile concrete will be validated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Concrete is strong in compression but weak in tension.  Under tensile load, concrete tends to crack losing its load-carrying capability.  Further, cracks in concrete allow easy access of water and salt to enter the structural element that can cause corrosion of the steel reinforcement, leading to a significant reduction in service life.  In many parts of the US, where de-icing salts are used on roadways or where structures are exposed to sea salts such as in coastal regions, deterioration of civil infrastructure caused by millimetre size concrete cracks and steel reinforcement corrosion lead to the need for repeated repairs, costly in both economic and environmental terms.  Road repair and detour commonly encountered by the general public illustrates these costs in addition to loss of time by motorists. Engineered Cementitious Composites (ECC), popularly known as bendable concrete, is the subject of study in this research due to its ability to control cracking.  Even when damaged, cracks in ECC are limited in width to less than the size of human hair, about 0.1 mm.  Specifically, this research attempts to develop fundamental understanding of how such microcracks would repair itself without external intervention, using only rain water and carbon dioxide in air. 

 

Specific objectives of this research includes: 1) Investigation of the influence of exposure type on self-healing and durability, including exposure of ECC to sulfate and chloride, and exposure to acid mine drainage; 2) Investigation of the composition of ECC on self-healing, including the addition of magnesium oxide and fly ash, the partial replacement of ordinary portland cement by limestone calcined clay (LCC) and polypropylene (PP) fiber, and the inclusion of titanium dioxide (TiO2); 3) The impact of self-healing on the permeability and stiffness recovery of damaged ECC; 4) The multi-scale modelling of stiffness recovery due to self-healing; and 5) the potential of application of ECC for durability enhancement for pavement and for cut-off walls as durable barrier to industrial mine drainage.  

 

The key outcomes of this research include a deeper understanding of self-healing of ECC, and development of a database of self-healing functionality measured in terms of recovery in permeability, stiffness and resonance frequency (RF).  It is verified that self-healing in ECC is more than the sealing of cracking that influences permeability, but represents a recovery of mechanical properties including composite stiffness.  Novel approaches adopting MgO or TiO2 for deliberate enhancement of self-healing has been identified in this research program. As well, it was discovered that the self-healing functionality appeared robust in a variety of exposure conditions, including some highly aggressive ones such as acid-mine drainage, and combined sulphate and chloride attack.  These outcomes advance the technology readiness level (TRL) of ECC as a large volume construction material that has built-in self-repair capability.  Potential application targets include jointless highway pavements, hydraulic structures, cut-off walls for toxic mining waste containment, and off-shore wind turbine tower.

 

The major activities include experimental and theoretical modelling research on self-healing.  Most of the research findings have been disseminated via publication and conference/workshop presentations. In all, four journal papers were published in top journals (with two additional paper pending, under review) and three presentations were given at international conferences with refereed proceedings.  Three PhD students, three undergraduates and three post-docs have been trained.  Our Laboratory also hosted six visiting scholars who collaborated in research activities.
